title: Can an electric guitar play an acoustic sound? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are couple of choices you can dive into if you want to SIMULATE an acoustic sound but none of this will truly REPLICATE the sound and richness of acoustic guitar. 1. EQ pedal: Yes, you are probably shocked but an Equalizer pedal is built for you to mess around with the frequency output of the electric guitar. An Acoustic guitar sound has a more low end frequency output, a subtle amount of mids and treble. Just experiment with those tiny sliders until you find the acoustic sound you want.2. D.I. Box and Home Stereo System. Like number one, home stereo systems have an equalizer for you to mess with (some even have separate for left and right channels). The D.I. Box is there to provide consistency of signal flow from your guitar to the microphone input (thats your entrance gate to the home stereo) to cancel the annoying effect of impedance miss match.3. Acoustic guitar simulator pedals.This is the most worry free of all the choices. Just plug and play. If you desire you can adjust the settings for presence, top, and even emulate the sound of 12 stringed guitar. They come on stompbox form or as a preset patch on most multi effects guitar processors.4. Piezo Pickup.Like our quoran friends here suggests, a piezo pickup can nearly simulate the acoustic sound your are looking for. Just a piece of advice, do not install it DIRECTLY the metal bridge. Keep several millimeters away from bridge and attach it to the wood. I would say, it in most effective if your guitar is a hollow body..... Hope all this will help you...

A Godin LGX (SA) guitar has a piezo transducer and can play an ‘acoustic’ sound, in the sense that the sound coming from a piezo transducer on an acoustic guitar is ‘acoustic’. It is never quite the same as an acoustic guitar. Played through a Roland VG-99, you can get a very good acoustic sound from the Godin’s GK pickup, or you can fit a Roland GK pickup to almost any guitar. This is through guitar modelling. This will generally produce a better acoustic sound on stage than an acoustic guitar would fitted with a piezo transducer. If you want to do this, you need to set up your Godin carefully, with a slightly higher action than you would normally take and with minimum .010 string gauge. Otherwise, even though the sound can model an acoustic guitar, the response of the guitar will be wrong. When setting up the VG-99, you need to turn down the gain on the strings to about 20, instead of around 70 which is more usual. Otherwise they will clip on the highest resonance, as an electric guitar does, and the illusion is lost. I learned to do this via VGuitar forums, http://vguitarforums.com. Before I turned down the gain, I was getting an acousticish but not really authentic sound. If you want to get an acoustic sound from an amplified acoustic guitar via its piezo transducer, then consider getting a Fishman Aura or equivalent. The Aura processes the transducer sound to be much more like the original guitar sound. Some people say it’s good enough for the studio, though I don’t agree, but it does sound extremely authentic live.

The original question was whether one can play acoustic guitar songs on an electric guitar, which has nothing to do with the question with which it has been thoughtlessly merged. One can certainly play acoustic guitar songs on an electric guitar. It won’t sound quite the same but tweaking tone controls, etc., can bring it close. More importantly, however, is that the essence of a song is quite malleable. Cover bands regularly walk onto a stage and play a variety of songs originally played by a wide range of artists. Each of those songs was originally recorded with one or more specific types of guitars, specific amplifiers, equalization, effects pedals, studio wizardry, etc. and yet many a cover band guitar player will walk in with their favorite guitar and amp, plug in, set the controls to their favorite setting, and proceed to play every song without changing a thing — perhaps they might add an effects pedal here or there, or choose a different pickup, etc., but that’s about as far as they go to remain faithful to the original. And yet, few in the audience will be the wiser, and even those who do recognize the variance from the original likely won’t care. Playing an acoustic guitar song on an electric guitar? Piece of cake.

As Sunny says you could install piezo pickup in your electric guitar, so you now would have a solid body acoustic guitar. It does sounds pretty close to a pickup recorded acoustic guitar (about the half of the video).  Powerbridge | Fishman Not cheap, but pretty convincing. You could even improve the sound with a pedal like this.  A Fishman Aura, or even a TC-Electronics Body Rez would do. But this way you end paying more than the cost of a middle range acoustic :-) The other way is using an electric guitar with an acoustic modeling pedal.  Perhaps not so accurate but far cheaper :-) even with a cheapo clone like this one I’m using (20$ in a chinese e-shop):  Keep in mind your amp will colour the sound too, you need a very clean channel to sound “acoustic”.

I have an Epiphone Ultra III with a piezo pickup. One of what would be a tone control on a stock Les Paul is used to blend the piezo and magnetic pickups. I’ve found that it has a plausible acoustic sound with the right amp settings (meaning, generally, clean, neutral EQ and no distortion). You can play acoustic songs that would resemble playing them on a real acoustic to an extent. You won’t fool anyone and this won’t fly in an “acoustics only” venue. I believe the guitar was made for that era of sounds that started off acoustic, went electric, then full distortion, then electric then ended acoustically. It’s credible enough that you could get away with not having an acoustic on a stand to play the acoustic parts of such songs. It’s not a substitute for when you want a full acoustic guitar sound.

Ish. They can make acoustic-ish sounds. Specifically, electric guitars with a little resonance and equipped with piezo pickups can imitate acoustic guitars. They cannot make acoustic guitar sounds - at least not those that are typical of popular acoustic guitars (e.g., Martin and Taylor). Bob Dylan could not sing Chimes of Freedom with an electric guitar and piezo and sound like Bob Dylan. Same with Bruce Springsteen and State Trooper. The instruments are just too differently designed.

You can play a guitar with a Roland or “Roland-compatible” pickup into a device that models an acoustic sound. A Roland pickup is hexophonic—six pickups in one to get the sound of each string separately. This facilitates more accurate modeling (as well as individual string pitch shifting and panning and other cool stuff). I play a solid-body Godin LGX-SA through a Roland VG=99 and a Roland GR-55. These (among many other things) both model various types of acoustic guitars. The result is okay—but nobody is going to think you’re playing a vintage Martin. Line Six used to make a line of “Variax” electric guitars that did internal modeling. They can sound pretty good.

As the video examples prove an electric guitar with any sort of magnetic pickups or emulators or whatever simply do not/cannot sound like an acoustic guitar. They CAN sound like an acoustic guitar which is fitted with an under saddle transducer, which means that it is effectively converting the acoustic guitar into an electric guitar. To some the differences might be acceptable but not to acoustic guitar players. the best way to amplify an acoustic guitar is to use good quality microphones out side of the body, and correctly positions.

It's hard to simulate the richness of an acoustic guitar but here are a few ways that can make your electric guitar sound like an acoustic guitar: You you can install an Hexaphonic pickup on your guitar which can be plugged to a Roland guitar synthesiser. This will probably give you the best results. Not only you will be able to simulate acoustic guitar but any instrumentplug your Electric guitar in a acoustic simulator pedal like those made by Roland.Use an acoustic guitar amp simulator with apps like Amplitude or Jam up pro.Use your piezo pickup if you have one on your electric guitar or use an equaliser pedal to lower the mid range of your guitar but this solution is less likely to give results as the first 2.Use a chorus and an Eq pedal plus a single coil middle pickup.How this helps.

Sort of. Piezo saddle pickups on an electric don't sound very much like an acoustic guitar because a solid body electric guitar is built not to vibrate. I've had considerably better results with a hexaphonic pickup and the Roland Virtual Guitar modeling processor. Still, if you want an acoustic guitar sound it's far better to get it from an acoustic guitar.

In short, no. An electric guitar was never designed and has never been expected to sound like an acoustic. If you want an electric guitar sound like an acoustic model, install piezo saddles in the bridge. That’ll be as close as you can get without a bunch of complex sound modeling. By the way, a piezo bridge will cost almost as much as a whole acoustic guitar.

Can an electric guitar play an acoustic sound? Here is a video of Pete Townsend playing “Pinball Wizard” live in concert on his Gibson SG. I think he does a superb job capturing the dynamics and the drama of the studio version, which relied on overdubbed acoustic and electric guitars. John Entwistle’s bass work is perfect in this live arrangement, as well.

You can install a piezoelectric pickup and it will give you acoustic type sounds. There are several models of electric guitars that are designed as acoustics to be played electric - usually with nylon strings. The Chet Atkins model and also a few by Godin come to mind.

Yes I have a guitar pedal that does that. It’s not perfect but it’s great sounding. I use the Boss AC-3 Acoustic Simulator. It made me think so I bought it and it does a pretty good job at sounding like an acoustic.

They're thinner than standard acoustics, and don't sound quite as full, but they're pretty close even unplugged. And they also have the full pickups and electronics (usually two humbuckers) from an electric.

Pure acoustic guitar, no. Electroacoustic guitar, yes. The simulators is out of the question. Look for a fishman power ridge. .
